1 JANUARY: 1 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:1 LESSON Troublesome transition VERSE 1 And it came to pass after this, that David inquired of the LORD, saying, Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah? And the LORD said unto him, Go up. And David said, Whither shall I go up? And he said, Unto Hebron. With the deaths of Saul and crown prince Jonathan, David was next in line to be king. He had been anointed by Samuel "in the midst of his brethren" [1 Samuel 16:13]. While the LORD had prepared and ordained David to be the next king of Israel, the transition would not be easy. There were Israelites still loyal to Saul. There was going to be prolonged battle between the house of Saul and the house of David [2 Samuel 3:1]. The civil war would pit brother against brother, friend against friend. There were few who could put aside kinship for the sake of truth. And this resulted in the conflation of political allegiances and personal vengeances. Grievances between individuals became the reason for dissension. It would have been less heart-breaking if the fight were taken to the real enemy. But it is tragic when brothers take up arms against one another. But that is how it is also with conflicts within the local church. Parties are formed not on the grounds of truth but on personal friendships. Are there legitimate reasons to leave a church? Absolutely, when the church has deviated from the Word of God and preaches another Gospel. But more often than not, the source of conflict within the church is selfish ambition. The Corinthian church was divided because there were people who said, "I am of Paul; and I of Apollos; and I of Cephas; and I of Christ" [1 Corinthians 1:12]. Factionalism did not arise because of Paul, Apollos, or Cephas. It was the "I" that was the cause of the dissension. As we begin a new year, let every God-fearing Christian resolve to "keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace" [Ephesians 4:3]. THOUGHT Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. 2 JANUARY: 2 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:1 LESSON Seeking God's will VERSE 1 And it came to pass after this, that David inquired of the LORD, saying, Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah? And the LORD said unto him, Go up. And David said, Whither shall I go up? And he said, Unto Hebron. As a fugitive on the run and leading a group of "misfits" [1 Samuel 22:2], things were simpler for David. Survival then was the chief objective. But now that he was thrust into leading a country, the work was more complex. It was no longer living from day to day, having enough to eat and finding a place to rest for the night. Now David had the responsibility to care for his people and to protect them from foreign enemies. So, David rightly "inquired of the LORD". This has been David's practice before he ascended to the throne and while he was king [1 Samuel 23:2, 4; 2 Samuel 2:1; 5:19, 23; 21:1]. There is no doubt David had a possible course of action in mind. Perhaps he would have been urged to make the move to secure the throne. But David would not rely on his own judgement. There were other occasions when David did not inquire of the LORD, as when he fled to Gath and had to feign madness there. There is a difference between inquiring and not inquiring of the LORD. The latter is marked by an unsettled hastefulness of spirit accompanied by turmoil and uncertainty. It is like a drowning man grasping at any and every thing. The former is characterised by unhurried poise and quiet restfulness. That is what prayer and waiting on the LORD does. It is not inertness; it is active dependence. It is not inaction; it is living faith. David makes no effort to secure the throne other than to "inquire of the LORD", and the LORD directed his steps forward. 3 JANUARY: 3 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:2-3 LESSON Hebron VERSE 3 And his men that were with him did David bring up, every man with his household: and they dwelt in the cities of Hebron. David had in mind a general direction he should take. He asked the LORD, "Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah?" [2 Samuel 2:1]. It was wise on his part to head toward Judah. It was the tribe he belonged to. It was home. He could be certain of the support of friends and the elders of Judah [1 Samuel 30:26]. When David further inquired which of the cities in Judah he should go, the LORD directed him toward Hebron. Formerly known as Kirjatharba [Genesis 23:2], the city of Hebron was situated some thirty kilometres south of Jerusalem. Hebron was well suited to be the temporary capital of David's reign for geographical, historical and sacred reasons. Geographically, Hebron was located in a strong position in the Judean mountains [Joshua 20:7]. David would be among friends there. Historically, Hebron was the place where Abraham bought a burial plot for Sarah [Genesis 23]. Hebron was also the place given to Caleb for an inheritance after he drove out the Anakims [Joshua 14:12-13]. Additionally, Hebron was a city of the priests, and later designated a city of refuge [Joshua 21:13]. The choice of Hebron as the capital would set the right tone to the start of David's reign, and it was the LORD's doing. David's situation is quite similar to Abraham's servant who was tasked to find a wife for Isaac. When he had found Rebekah, the servant prayed, "I being in the way, the LORD led me ..." [Genesis 24:27]. David was being in the right way, and the LORD led him exactly, and so will He do the same for you. The path of righteousness is the general direction that believers should take; the exact route is determined by the will of God, and we can be sure that the destination is always glorious. 4 JANUARY: 4 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:4 LESSON David's coronation VERSE 4 And the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. And they told David, saying, That the men of Jabesh-gilead were they that buried Saul. This would be David's second anointing. The first was private, witnessed only by his brothers [1 Samuel 16:13]. The second at Hebron was public. The men of Judah came and anointed David. In so doing, they remembered the last blessings of Jacob upon Judah that "the sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet" [Genesis 49:10a]. In anointing David, the men of Judah were not king-makers; they were not putting the son of Jesse on the throne. The anointing was merely a recognition of the choice of the sovereign God and His will that David should be king after Saul's death. Anointing is a common Jewish practice of putting oil on the head. It is applied to guests as an act of hospitality [Psalm 23:5; Luke 7:46]; to dead persons [Mark 14:8; 16:1]. Anointing is also done on joyous occasions [Psalm 45:7, 92:10; Ecclesiastes 9:8; Hebrews 1:9], and to cease anointing is a mark of mourning [2 Samuel 14:2; Daniel 10:3; Matthew 6:17]. Anointing as seen in our text is the act of consecration, to render a thing or person fit for holy use [Leviticus 4:3; Exodus 29:29, 30:26]. The high priest and the king are thus called "the anointed" [Leviticus 4:3,5,16; 6:20; Psalm 132:10]. The promised Deliverer is twice called the "Anointed" or Messiah [Psalm 2:2], and Jesus of Nazareth is this Anointed One [John 1:41; Acts 9:22, 17:2-3, 18:5], the Messiah of the Old Testament. Anointing is applied also to Christians as being consecrated, set apart for the service of God by the Holy Spirit [2 Corinthians 1:21; 1 John 2:27]. This act spells out our privilege (anointed by God) as well as our responsibility (anointed for God). 5 JANUARY: 5 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:4 LESSON The men of Jabesh-Gilead VERSE 4 And the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. And they told David, saying, That the men of Jabesh-gilead were they that buried Saul. The first recorded act of David was to commend the men of Jabesh-gilead. They retrieved the mutilated bodies of Saul and his sons, cremated and buried them. The account of what they did is recorded in 1 Samuel 31:11-13. Jabesh-Gilead was situated east of Jordan, located within the territory of the half tribe of Manasseh. The inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead are first mentioned in connection with their refusal to join the rest of the tribes at Mizpeh in punishing the Benjamites. The entire sordid affair is recorded in Judges 20-21. There, some men from Gibeah (which was part of Benjamin) committed a grave atrocity. When the rest of the tribes confronted the Benjamites, they refused to hand over the men of Gibeah who committed the dastardly act. As a result, a civil war ensued. The other tribes also made a vow that they would not allow their daughters to marry Benjamite men which would effectually lead to depletion of the Benjamites. To get out of this vow subsequently, the Israelites massacred the inhabitants of Jabesh- Gilead who had not participated in the war against the Benjamites, sparing only four hundred virgins found there, who were later given to the Benjamite remnant. The next mention of Jabesh-Gilead was when Saul delivered them from the Ammonites [1 Samuel 11]. It was in response to this deliverance that the men of Jabesh-Gilead risked their lives to retrieve the bodies of Saul and his three sons from the walls of Beth-shan. David, upon coming to the throne, recognised the virtue of gratitude and commended the inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead for their act of piety. It has been said that it is wise to have for our friends those who have shown themselves to be grateful and faithful to others. Instead David commended them - a commendation that was well deserved because the men of Jabesh- Gilead returned kindness with kindness; they repaid faithfulness with faithfulness; and their act was one of respect, as John Gill pointed out "to bury the dead, with the Jews, was always reckoned an instance of humanity and kindness, and indeed of piety; an act done in imitation of God, who buried Moses, and so it might be expected the divine blessing would attend it." The men of Jabesh-Gilead could have absolved themselves of this reciprocal act of kindness, but they did not. Thus, David not only sent messengers to Jabesh-Gilead with a beatitude - "Blessed be ye of the LORD, that ye have shewed this kindness unto your lord, even unto Saul, and have buried him" [2 Samuel 2:5b], but he also took it upon himself to promise kindness to the people of Jabesh-Gilead. If David would do that, how much more the greater David, our Lord Jesus. On one occasion, He commended the disciples for feeding Him when He was hungry, giving Him drink when He was thirsty and clothing Him when He was naked. The disciples were incredulous and asked when it was they showed kindness to Him, and Jesus replied, "Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me" [Matthew 25:45]. 8 JANUARY: 8 JANUARY BIBLE LESSON 2 Samuel 2:8 LESSON Abner VERSE 8 But Abner the son of Ner, captain of Saul's host, took Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim. Now with Saul gone, Abner, in a power-play, crowned Ish-bosheth, one of Saul's son, king of Israel. There are at least three possible reasons for Abner's move - kinship ties, personal gain, and blind patriotism. First, Ner, Abner's father, was Saul's uncle [1 Samuel 14:50, 20:25, 26:5]. That meant Abner was the cousin of Saul and uncle of Ish-bosheth. The throne must be kept in the house of Saul. Second, Abner was a general of Saul's army. If none of Saul's sons succeeded him, Abner's position as general of his army was also at stake - a position that he coveted. Third, blind loyalty that drove Abner to see his loyalty to the house of Saul as more important than his obedience to the will of God. It has been said that virtues cease to be virtues when they are exercised apart from the Word of God. While Abner's loyalty to his king and his desire to see Saul's house continue were commendable, he failed to follow the higher law and obey the supreme will of God. Abner's error was that he failed to see it was God's will that David would be the next king, and that his loyalty to the throne must be rendered to the man whom God has chosen. We are duty bound to love our country. Our Lord Jesus told the disciples that they are to render "unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's" [Matthew 22:21]. However, Peter saw no contradiction when he told the Sanhedrin, "We ought to obey God rather than men" [Acts 5:29]. The reason is that we are bound to obey God and submit to His supreme will. We must exercise our devotion to men within the expressed will of God; if not, it would be a violation of the First Commandment. TO COMPLETE THE BIBLE IN 2 YEARS, READ GENESIS 8 MATTHEW 8

But the house of Judah followed David. David was crowned king of Judah in Hebron; however, his coronation was not well received by those still loyal to Saul. With support for David's reign not firm yet, Abner, the general of Saul's army, took Saul's remaining son and made him king over Gilead. Ish-bosheth was the fourth and last son of Saul. Three other sons - Jonathan, and Malchi-shua, and Abinadab - were killed in battle together with Saul. At the time of the battle against the Philistines, Ish-bosheth would be in his thirties; that he did not follow his father and brothers into battle was perhaps a sign of his weak physical constitution. His name bears that out as well. Ish-bosheth means "man of shame". In 1 Chronicles 8:33, he was originally known as Esh-baal (see also 1 Chronicles 9:39), which also means "man of Baal" or "man of the master". Baal was replaced with "Bosheth" only later when it became associated with the Phoenician deity. The personalities of Ish-bosheth, Abner and David are examples of three kinds of people whom we see in political and business domains, and even in Christian circles. Ish-bosheth is the weak one, lacking in character and courage. He is the one who gets to where he is because of his connections. His "strengths" are his birth and heritage. Abner is the king-maker. He is the power behind the facade. He is the one who knows how to manipulate others for his own personal profit, and he has no qualms in switching sides as long as it is to his advantage. David is the man whose heart is after God. While he was called and anointed to serve God, he got to where he was from the bottom rung - from shepherd to king. The Judean wilderness was his training ground not just for his kingship but also for his service to God.
